DOOM Eternal takes everything that made DOOM (2016) great and pushes it even further. It is faster, harder, smarter, and more intense in every possible way. The result is one of the most exhilarating and skill-based shooters ever made.

Gameplay & Fun

The gameplay in DOOM Eternal is pure chaos ‚Äî in the best possible way. Movement is quicker, combat arenas are bigger, and enemies are more aggressive.
What really stands out is how much the game encourages you to think while fighting. Ammo, armor, and health all depend on using different tools:

Chainsaw for ammo

Flame belch for armor

Glory kills for health

This system makes every battle feel like a fast-paced puzzle where you‚Äôre constantly switching weapons, abilities, and movement tricks. When everything ‚Äúclicks,‚Äù the game becomes insanely fun and satisfying.

Challenge

DOOM Eternal is significantly more challenging than DOOM (2016). Even normal difficulty requires you to stay active, aim well, and use every part of your kit.
Enemies have weak points, special behaviors, and attack patterns you need to learn. It‚Äôs a game that respects your skill and expects you to improve.
If you enjoy mastery and want a shooter that actually tests you, this game delivers that perfectly.

Story

Surprisingly, DOOM Eternal expands the DOOM universe with much deeper lore. You get more information about the Doom Slayer‚Äôs past, Hell‚Äôs hierarchy, the Maykrs, and the wider universe.
The story is bigger, more cinematic, and has epic moments that feel almost mythological.
Even though DOOM is an action-focused series, Eternal manages to tell a more ambitious story without slowing down the gameplay.

 Soundtrack & Effects

Mick Gordon‚Äôs soundtrack is legendary. The heavy industrial metal vibes perfectly match the game‚Äôs pace, and when the music hits during a fight, it feels incredible.
The sound effects are brutal and crisp, with every weapon having a strong and unique impact.
Visually, DOOM Eternal is stunning:

Bright, detailed environments

Smooth animations

Ridiculously cool demon designs

Explosive particle effects

It‚Äôs one of the best-looking and best-sounding shooters on the market.

Overall Experience

DOOM Eternal is a masterpiece of fast, skill-based FPS gameplay. It‚Äôs a game that constantly pushes you to improve, rewards aggressive play, and delivers unforgettable combat encounters.
It‚Äôs bigger, louder, and more ambitious than DOOM (2016) ‚Äî and it absolutely succeeds.

If you want a shooter that gives you speed, challenge, and style all at once, DOOM Eternal is a must-play.

More of a thumbs sideways, but giving a thumbs down because for the opportunity cost of 20 hours, you can do much better:

Pros:
-Great level design
-Great enemy design, they fun to fight (except for the marauder)
-Weapons are unique, feel fantastic, and are customizable to your own liking
-Movement and platforming are a lot of fun

Cons:
-The game gets worse the longer you play. It's completely overstimulating with all the flashing lights, lightning fast gameplay and hyper aggressive enemies
-After a while through the campaign, there is nothing new. Encounters are just existing enemy types spawned in ever increasing quantities. Eventually the arenas get smaller and smaller and more and more stressful to play in. Enemies start spawning behind you and inevitably box you in, leading to some frustrating moments.
-Story is incomprehensible for the player unless you take a deep dive into all the text codices found in-game. Even if you try reading everything, the story is still just weird and uninteresting. It gave me little motivation to continue.
-There isn't really anything to break up the gameplay loop, which becomes tedious after a while. You shoot, platform, and sometimes stop to upgrade your weapons, then repeat. This is a problem for all shooters, but Doom Eternal does not do much to address it.
-Secrets hidden throughout the levels may be seen as good game design to encourage exploration, but I disagree. 
They encouraged me to constantly alt+tab to an external guide so I don't miss anything. I could have just missed them, but that is no fun.

I finished it, but felt like I did it more out of obligation than out of enjoyment. Here are two other shooters that I would recommend you play instead:

Amid Evil - It doesn't do much to break up the core gameplay loop either, but I found this one more enjoyable and just as fast without being totally overwhelming after a while
Immortals of Aveum - This may be controversial, but I enjoyed this one much more than Doom. Story, though imperfect, was better, gameplay was just as good, customization was better, levels were just more beautiful, weapons were more interesting, just super slick. Check it out!

I can't believe I am saying this, but I am utterly disgusted as how little I like this game. There isn't any doom game that I disliked before as much as this one. I don't dislike this game 'cause it's bad but because it took the fun away from the franchise I actually love. Objectively speaking this is a good game, very polished, good controls, good shooting mechanics, etc, but the new added mechanics I absolutely despise.

     First and foremost I hate the extremely limited ammo on guns and the mandatory chainsaw mechanic to collect ammo. It led to a repetitive gameplay loop where I used a gun to kill 2 big guys, switch to another gun kill 2 more, switch to another gun kill 2 more, chainsaw a little guy return to the same loop. It killed player expression and agency on how to approach combat. You either FOLLOW the correct way to play or suffer for it.
     Second I can't main a gun, me as a player I felt forced to use the correct gun for the correct demon or risk being punished for it.
     Third: There are way to many cooldowns to manage while there are way to many enemies and to little time to think about it. I assume they wanted you to be able to make strategic choices with the different tools you have like the flame thingie, ice grenade, punch, glory kills, double dodge, double jump but due to how encounters and arenas are designed it simply fails. There are to many enemies and they can simply spawn on top of you and when you are in the thick of it there is not time to think strategically you either react correctly or you don't. This had the consequence of you having to manage 4 different resources while dodging hundreds of projectile, running away from 10 - 15 demons, jumping, dodging, shooting while also keeping my eyes on the cooldowns for ammo recovery, health recovery, armor recovery, super punch recovery and gloy kills timing. Instead of having fun running around demolishing demons as a badass doomguy, most of the time it felt like I was playing a simulation game on how to manage resources. Do I have enough ammo? Is it time to chainsaw a guy? What about my health is it okay? Is my flame out of cd to recover some armor?? Should I glory kill the demon that is surrounded by 20 dudes? Or is it a death sentence?, etc
     Fifth: Level design felt plastic, artificial boring and lacked exploration. While I love parkouring the level design is just lacking. IT doesn't make sense in any kind of way. I would have understood that after earth we go to hell and we have floaty thingies everywhere, but as it stands every level feels false and unrealistic.
     Sixth: While they spent more time to develop the story than doom 2016 it felt worse in almost every way. I am the kind of guy that stops and read every lore entry but with this game it felt bad for some reason. I can't say why but so far I find the story to be lacking and confusing.
     Seventh: The plasma rifle design is atrociously ugly. One of my favorite guns in the series and they made it so freaking ugly. 

     I will probably push to finish the game and maybe play it on the hardest difficulty because I love a challenge but that is more due to my stubbornness and my  wish to get value form my purchase. If you want a good Doom game go back and play they 2016 one. I can't recommend this one.

I don't need an organization chart of Hell, I don't need a fleshed out backstory for Doomguy.  This is ruining the Doom Slayer created in Doom 2016 the way Jason Momoa's Conan ruins Conan. It's the disjointed environments that mess up the flow of battle that 2016 had.  There's too much getting cornered with no way to get ammo, too much finding yourself out in the open far from your enemies and they have no fucking chance, it's just all over the place.  I power through sections then hit a brick wall made out of a specific arrangement of low to mid enemies.  This would be okay, I guess, if the enemy tutorial items were actually useful. What it carries over from Doom 2016 it doesn't do as well.  What it adds is all pointless, annoying, or broken.

TL;DR: The game has some innovation and was partially fun, but becomes a slog and has some glaring issues. Check DOOM 2016 first and play this afterward if you still crave it.

A ton of the concepts are good and fun on paper. Weapon sandbox is very nice, dash is a good addition, infighting between demons still exists (as it should), and rooms are still well built for scrambles. The only problem I have with the weapons is some of them are strictly better picks than others. The [spoiler]unlockable BFG alternative[/spoiler] has strictly worse damage to ammo ratio, with practically no use given how few and far between that ammo type is. The scoped HMG takes too long for it's DPS in a game all about the scramble, and is only made good in one level due to a gimmick. Mini rocket HMG is such a busted pick for everything but the final boss, where it simply does not work. I could go on, but it's not that big an issue.

The story isn't really good (not what we are here for, let's be real) but the way they try to focus on it and make a worse story than DOOM 2016 (where they didn't try to focus on it as much) hurts my soul. The dialogue definitely isn't good either; Samuel emphasized TWICE that we needed to hurry in almost the exact same sentence with almost no gap between both instances. It also doesn't help when you hear Samuel tell you on repeat to speed up and then the game throws three 15-minute scramble fights with really strong enemies at you (the reuse of the gladiator boss as an enemy was the worst decision they could make for the game, anywhere he exist the fights go from rip-and-tear to run-and-tear and you are basically forced to isolate him).

Boss fights aren't their strong suit either, some of them are simple, others are ammo and DPS checks, and the final one forces you into an almost stalemate if he repeats the same move. On top of that, I spent 15 minutes per phase on the final boss, and before I could kill it, the game auto-killed it for me and jarringly threw me into the kill cutscene, before roll credits. I couldn't even get that last bit of satisfaction for killing the boss i spent time on, because they ripped it from my hands.

I really wish I could give this game a recommend, but the game became so much of a slog that I skipped collectible hunts and challenges on the last few levels just to get it over with, and ending the game with what felt like an ill-deserved boss kill is not a good feeling.
